sourceDesc.p: This publication constitutes a remediation of the printed Inns of Court collection. Information on original sources for transcriptions can be accessed via the Document Descriptions.
For a full list of REED collections, editors, executive board members, and staff, please visit http://reed.utoronto.ca/people

prefixDef.p: Private URIs using the taxon prefix are pointers to entities in the taxonomy.xml file. For example, taxon:church dereferences to taxonomy.xml#church.
Private URIs using the gloss prefix are pointers to entities in the glossary.xml file. For example, gloss:histrio-1 dereferences to glossary.xml#histrio-1.

projectDesc.p: Records of Early English Drama (REED) is an international scholarly project that is establishing for the first time the context from which the drama of Shakespeare and his contemporaries grew. Founded in 1976, REED has worked since then to locate, transcribe, and edit historical documents containing evidence of drama, secular music, and other communal entertainment and ceremony from the Middle Ages until 1642, when the Puritans closed the London theatres.

revisionDesc.change: adapted schema from #JC work on Staffordshire

head.supplied: Letter of the Middle Temple to the Earl of Shrewsbury

div.ab: Right honorable Lord we send you humble and hearty greetinge, forasmuch as the ordinarie expence of our publique hospitalitie is such and soe great at all times in the knowledge and view of all men of right understandinge and consideracion and that by new vnexpected accidentes of forraine chardge and enterteinmentes the same is at this present soe greatlye augmented and encreased, that without a beneuolent Largess and contribution of the members and wellwishers of this howse the same cannot well be defraied and dischardged, These are therefore to request your honor as you tender the loues of vs your fellowes and allyes and the grace and reputation of this fellowship whereof we repute and hold you a worthy and principall member and fauourer, to Lend us such a somme of moneye as to your honor shall seem conuenient in fauour of our pretented extraordinarye designes, which wee promise to repaye vnto you the xxxth day of februariexxxth day of februarie: ie, never next at our Threasurye, from whence we bid you heartylye farewell
div.closer: Your very Louinge friendes Middle Temple.

div.head: [Endorsement]
div.ab: This privy seale beynge brought vnto me at Christemas 1597. In respect of ye Prince d’Amores kepinge his revells in ye Inn of Cowrte I send him by ye handes of Mr Davyes of ⎡that⎤ house–30 li.
div.closer: Your very Louinge friendes Middle Temple. (signed) Gilbert Shrewsbury
div.note: Though Green [Inns of Court, p 102] queries the date of Christmas 1597–8, preferring instead Christmas 1599–1600, the date of ‘Le Prince d’Amour alias Noctes Templariae’ is established by the earl of Shrewsbury’s dated endorsement of a letter from the Middle Temple
